stream_context.summary: Kaze builds and refines an "ice-castle" course for Return to Yoshi’s Island, concentrating on flow-heavy slide mechanics, mirrored ice walls, wind windows and an eventual giant-raven boss. The session is almost entirely level-design iteration: plotting star routes, adding warps, testing camera angles and tweaking physics while postponing visual polish.

development_findings.summary: Level theme revolves around slides and “slight-momentum” jumps; many paths are built so players can chain slide-long-jumps rather than standard platforms.
development_findings.quote: I made a lot of this castle to be about sliding and slight momentum jumps.

development_findings.summary: Overall difficulty is intended to sit near vanilla SM64 but feel fairer thanks to more consistent controls and option-based risk.
development_findings.quote: Some of this may look more difficult, but the controls in this game are a lot more consistent, so that hopefully makes up for the difficulty.

development_findings.summary: A mirrored-ice wall section is being prototyped so players wall-kick against their reflection; Kaze is weighing N64 performance costs of rendering multiple Marios and may restrict the mirror to one side.
development_findings.quote: What if just one side was mirrored and the other wasn’t? Hall of mirrors is still doable… Yeah, but I’m on an N64. Do you really want that?

development_findings.summary: Windows that push Mario with wind will double as obstacles or assists; Kaze plans to reuse this mechanic throughout the castle.
development_findings.quote: The cool thing about the window, it can be an obstacle or a helper.

development_findings.summary: Star layout (in-progress): 1) glass-cased gauntlet star, 2) snowman cave slide path, 3) boss fight with big raven, 4) reds outside, 5) 8-bit pipe hidden in a ‘jail’ cell, 6) cold-haze underground rooms.
development_findings.quote: First star, platforming gauntlet… boss fight with the big raven… I think that feels nice and open.

development_findings.summary: Ice walls will replace traditional jail bars, showing frozen enemies for atmosphere and avoiding tile repetition.
development_findings.quote: What if instead of jail cells, this is just like frozen walls and there’s people behind the frozen walls.

development_findings.summary: Camera problems in tight rooms led to deleting an entire connector room and reallocating space so the camera can pull back smoothly.
development_findings.quote: This level very much is form-follows-function… we’re still figuring out the platforming so we don’t waste time making it pretty.

development_findings.summary: Kaze insists on staying within 64 MB and original N64 specs; fancy ideas (DLSS-style upscaling, neural nets) are only pursued if they can run on real hardware.
development_findings.quote: I do want to do this whole thing with the hardware of the time.

development_findings.summary: Source code for the hack will be released, but only after the full mod ships to prevent leaks and premature clones.
development_findings.quote: If I release it before then I dig my whole mod… I’ll release [the source] whenever my mod’s done.

development_findings.summary: Visual pass is deferred until all platforming is locked, preventing wasted art effort.

context_findings.summary: Kaze avoids praising AI publicly due to perceived Twitter backlash despite personal interest in ML on N64.
context_findings.quote: Legit, I’m at a point where I won’t say that anything AI is cool publicly because I think I will literally be murdered on twitter.com.

context_findings.summary: He prides himself on frugality: once lived on €300/month (220 rent) and keeps project costs low; sees cartridge sales and tools as investments.
context_findings.quote: I used to live off of 300 euros every month and 220 of those were rent.

context_findings.summary: Work philosophy: programming languages should be simple tools, not arbitrary challenges.
context_findings.quote: Programming is something you do to build something. The act of it itself should be as simple as possible.

context_findings.summary: Streaming helps him focus but juggling chat, level design and technical tasks is mentally taxing.
context_findings.quote: It is kind of hard to pay attention to everything going on at the same time while also developing a game.

context_findings.summary: Shows playful frustration with web tools (Restream, Node.js) and general skepticism toward large cars/pop-culture status symbols—mostly comedic.

biobak.summary: Suggested using a swirling ‘void’ texture for bottomless pits, which Kaze implemented and liked for slides.
biobak.quote: This looks extremely cool to me.

key_stories.title: Designing the Mirror Wall
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants a section where Mario wall-kicks against a mirror, seeing his reflection. Performance worries about drawing multiple Marios create a design debate.
key_stories.challenge: Add a visually striking mirror mechanic without overloading N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed hall-of-mirrors ideas with chat; considered limiting reflections to one side or fewer rendered clones.
key_stories.outcome: Concept kept but scaled: likely a single-sided mirror implementation; details still pending.
key_stories.key_quote: I’m on an N64—do you really want that?

key_stories.title: Camera-Driven Room Deletion
key_stories.summary: A connector room caused severe camera issues during slide traversal. Rather than fight the engine, Kaze cut the room and redistributed space.
key_stories.challenge: Tight indoor geometry made the camera unpredictable and disorienting.
key_stories.process: Tested jumps, identified blind spots, removed the room, widened remaining space, subdivided walls so the camera could pull back.
key_stories.outcome: Platforming flow improved and camera now behaves; visual polish postponed.
key_stories.key_quote: We don’t want to spend any time making it pretty before we don’t have the platforming.

key_stories.title: Mapping the Six-Star Layout
key_stories.summary: Kaze systematically walks through each planned star, ensuring unique routes and mechanics while balancing difficulty.
key_stories.challenge: Need coherent objectives that encourage exploration without overlap.
key_stories.process: Listed each star, traced required paths, inserted warps, adjusted heights to prevent dead ends.
key_stories.outcome: Preliminary star blueprint finished; two rooms and underground fog area still to build.
key_stories.key_quote: First star, platforming gauntlet to a star you see early on, but can’t reach until later.

open_questions.context: Boss entrance planned after ice-block stairs; only concept discussed.
